title: school football | Westerville Central's defense helps hold off Hilliard Bradley
text:
There seemed to be enough Westerville Central players on crutches, in slings and limping around on Friday night to field another football team against Hilliard Bradley.
The refrain from coach John Magistro since standout receiver Cedric Frierson was lost for the season to a torn knee ligament in the second week of the season has been “next man up.”
“We’ve had 22 players out with injuries,” Magistro said. “We’ve got three seniors who are done for the year. We are so depleted, and I’m so proud of our guys for stepping up. I know we can look ugly, but we’re finding a way. Wins are wins.”

The task is more difficult with starting quarterback Gavin Lyon out indefinitely because of a sprained right (throwing) shoulder. But backup Daniel Kreuzer connected with Andrew Wallace for a 78-yard touchdown, Benny Snell ran for an 8-yard score and the defense came up with four stops in the second half as the Warhawks defeated the Jaguars 14-9 at Bradley.
Somehow, Westerville Central (6-0, 3-0) is in first place in the Ohio Capital Conference Cardinal Division and second to 2014 state champion Lakewood St. Edward in the Division I, Region I computer playoff standings.
The defense came to the rescue against Bradley. It delivered a stand at the Warhawks 6-yard line that resulted in a missed field-goal attempt, sacks on third down by Chima Ibezin and Daniel Rucker that ended drives and a breakup of a fourth-down pass by David Rucker with 1:13 remaining.
“We’re prepared to play every game,” linebacker Colin Robertson said. “We trust in each other every single play. Everyone does his job. We never let down because we’re workers. We take a lot of pride in what we do. We think we’ve got the best defense in central Ohio.”
Wallace and Robertson stopped the ball carrier cold on third-and-goal for a 4-yard loss near the end of the third quarter, and Bradley missed a 27-yard field-goal attempt.
On third-and-4 at the Jaguars 48 in the fourth quarter, Ibezin sacked Chance Levitt for a 9-yard loss.
On the next possession, Daniel Rucker broke through the line to tackle Levitt for a 7-yard loss on third-and-9, dropping him at the Warhawks 38.
Finally, David Rucker, playing cornerback, got a hand on the ball and ripped it away from receiver Derek Dunnagan on fourth-and-7 near midfield.
“I played it 5 yards off the line because I knew it would be something short,” David Rucker said. “When he broke, I followed him. He caught the ball, but I ripped it out. Coach just told us to come up with a play.”
Kreuzer, a Wright State baseball recruit who was on Westerville Central’s state-tournament baseball team, was exceptional in the first half in leading two touchdown drives for a 14-0 lead. He completed passes of 10, 11, 16 and 9 yards on a 70-yard touchdown drive that ended with an 8-yard run by Snell with 9:21 left in the first quarter.
Then Kreuzer threw over the middle to Wallace for a 78-yard touchdown with 1:50 left in the first half. Wallace stopped at the 30, cut back to the sideline and outran the defense to the pylon.
“That was a perfect pass,” Wallace said. “Daniel and I go back to pee-wee football, and we have chemistry. We had been working on that play the entire week. Daniel put the ball right there. I stopped and cut because my sophomore year, I got tackled from behind. I didn’t want that to happen again.”
